results.title: In sickness and in health: women and the health care system
results.creator_credit: Carole Sklan, John Moore, Healthsharing Women. Publishing and Production Group and Open Channel Productions
results.brief_description: Women are the most frequent users of the health care system, but have little say in the way it is run. This program outlines how women can deal with and what they need from the health care system. Includes interviews with sociologists, nurse educators, doctors and patients and is designed to awaken consumer and practitioner awareness of women’s rights in health care.
results.title_for_label: In sickness and in health: women and the health care system
results.creator_credit_for_label: Carole Sklan, John Moore, Healthsharing Women. Publishing and Production Group and Open Channel Productions

results.title: In shifting sands: the truth about UNSCOM and the disarming of Iraq
results.creator_credit: Scott Ritter, Alex Cohn and Five Rivers Productions
results.brief_description: Former United Nations weapons inspector Scott Ritter has compiled this series of interviews and footage into an interesting account of events leading up to the invasion of Iraq. The weapons inspectors were sent in on a supposedly non-political mission, their knowledge base being about weapons. Frustration with Iraqi officials denying them access to sites is shown and general dissatisfaction in the pressure brought to bear by politicians who were after a desired outcome. No definitive answers are given but the film provides some insight to the trying process the inspectors were put through. Please note that due to the nature of the original source material, the footage of “In shifting sands” is of a variable standard.

results.title: In season: an insider's guide to mixing and mating during the English social season
results.creator_credit: Paul Henman, Howard Webster and British Movietone News
results.brief_description: This is a light-hearted, tongue-in-cheek look at “The Season”, the time when the British aristocracy socialise and follow the Royals, when it is important to be seeing and being seen by those who count, and to attend major events such as Royal Ascot, Wimbledon, Polo, the Royal Academy, and the Henley Royal Regatta to name but a few. “The Season” takes place each summer in Britain but is it the same as it was in the past? Is it still important to be seen with the Royals, or even for the Royals to attend these highlight events on the social calendar? Has the social order changed allowing for almost a classless “Season” or is it still a case of who you know and how much money you have? Presenter and socialite Gay Close attempts to find the answers to these questions by taking to the streets and asking “the commoners” as well as conducting private and upfront interviews with famous British personalities including the Queen’s couturier and well-known fashion designer, Hardy Amies, Managing Director of Burke’s Peerage, Harold Brookes-Baker, Diary Editor of the Daily Express, Ross Benson, actress and singer Baroness Issy Van Randwyck and many others. Also includes black and white Movietone newsreel archival footage to provide a reflection of seasons past.

results.title: In search of the Japanese
results.creator_credit: Solrun Hoaas and Swinburne Institute of Technology. Film and Television School
results.brief_description: Stanley Burns, entrepreneur and thinker, decides to export Australiana to Japan and so, being the astute businessman he is, sets out to understand the inscrutable Japanese. This amusing comedy makes many allusions to Japanese film classics including a Samurai duel, a la Kurosawa, where the protagonists use chop-sticks instead of swords. Basically a satire on the enigma of Japanese culture as seen through western eyes. Cast: Roger Pulvers, Howard Stanley, Chong Weng Hoo, Ue Kyogo, Amanda Ma.

results.title: In search of the bowhead whale
results.creator_credit: Bill Mason, Colin Low, Bill Brind and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: An adventure film of a whaling expedition that included Scott McVay, an authority on whales, and filmmaker Bill Mason. The objective was to find and film the bowhead, a magnificent inhabitant of the cold Arctic seas brought to the edge of extinction by excessive commercial whaling. With helicopter and Inuit guide, aqualungs and underwater cameras, the expedition searches out and meets the bowhead and beluga. (Six awards, including New York; Columbus)

results.title: In search of myself
results.brief_description: Considers the conflicts encountered by the people of the emerging nations who want to utilise the best aspects of technologically advanced societies but also want their progress to be uniquely African in nature. Young Nigerian authors, artists and musicians discuss their opinions and experiences.

results.title: In search of innocence
results.creator_credit: Leonard Forest and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: A questioning filmmaker from Quebec finds out how Vancouver’s poets and painters look at life and art. Among the people seen are sculptor Donald Jarvis, painters Jack Shadbolt, Joy Long and Margaret Peterson, and printmaker Sing Lim. (Award: Chicago)

results.title: In search of golden footprints
results.creator_credit: Andrew Swift and ACMI Digital Storytelling
results.brief_description: Andrew Swift was raised in a small mining town in the foothills of the Victorian Alpine country. The more he learnt about the history of mining in the region, the more his interest in the remote areas of the Alps increased. Andrew’s exploration of the area has unearthed evidence of the long forgotton gold mines and the stories of the people who worked there.
